title: 3,000 Oreos Per Minute. One Machine.
body:
A single Oreo production line makes 3,000 cookies every 60 seconds. That's 50 per second.

The dough starts in a 2,000-pound mixing tub. Two kinds of cocoa and dry ice. A rotary molder stamps every cookie with that exact same pattern -- 12 dashes, 12 dots, 4 clovers. Each one identical to the millimeter.

The cream? Dispensed by a machine at exactly 3.5 grams per cookie. Not 3.4. Not 3.6. The line runs 24/7 producing over a billion cookies a year from a single factory.

Mondelez makes them. Ticker MDLZ. $90 billion company. And most of that value runs on machines no human ever touches.
cta: Next time -- 2,000 Coke cans per minute. This is Becknology, where markets meet machines.
broll: Oreo production line, rotary molder stamping cookies, cream filling dispenser

title: Rockwell Just Bet $2 Billion on American Factories
body:
Last week Rockwell Automation announced a 1-million-square-foot factory in New Berlin, Wisconsin. Their CEO Blake Moret called it the "factory of the future."

It's part of a $2 billion bet on domestic manufacturing over the next 5 years. This will be the largest Rockwell campus on Earth.

Think about that. The company that builds the brains for every assembly line in America just said: we're going bigger than we've ever gone. They also just bought their Mequon facility outright for $62.5 million.

Ticker ROK. This isn't reshoring hype. This is a $34 billion company putting real money down.
cta: Follow along. Next up -- the company hiding inside every vending machine. This is Becknology, where markets meet machines.
broll: Rockwell Automation HQ, PLC manufacturing line, construction site aerial

title: Your Razor Blade Is Sharp to 100 Nanometers
body:
The edge of your razor blade is ground to 100 nanometers. That's 1/1000th the width of a human hair.

A machine takes a strip of stainless steel, heats it to 1,100 degrees, quenches it, then grinds the edge in 3 passes. First pass: rough shape. Second: fine honing. Third: stropping to sub-micron precision.

Every blade on the line has to hit the same 100nm tolerance. One blade off and the batch fails quality control.

Gillette alone sells $6 billion worth of these per year. Parent company Procter & Gamble. Ticker PG. All built on a machine that sharpens metal thinner than a wavelength of light.
cta: Stick around. Next time we're looking at 120,000 Coke cans per hour. This is Becknology, where markets meet machines.
broll: Razor blade edge under electron microscope, steel grinding line, blade quality inspection

title: 2,000 Coke Cans Per Minute
body:
Coca-Cola's fastest line fills 2,000 cans every single minute. That's 33 cans per second.

Each can gets exactly 12 fluid ounces of syrup and carbonated water at 38 degrees Fahrenheit. Too warm and the CO2 escapes. Too cold and the line jams. The fill valve opens for 0.3 seconds per can.

1.9 billion Coke drinks are consumed every day. Not every year. Every day. The machines that make that possible run in 200+ countries.

Ticker KO. A $270 billion company that's really just a logistics and automation empire disguised as a drink.
cta: Next up -- the fiber optic cable carrying the internet at the speed of light. This is Becknology, where markets meet machines.
broll: Coca-Cola canning line, high-speed fill valve close-up, warehouse conveyor

title: One Glass Thread. 800 Terabits Per Second.
body:
A single fiber optic strand thinner than a human hair carries 800 terabits per second. Enough bandwidth to stream every Netflix show simultaneously.

Corning makes the glass. They heat silica to 2,000 degrees Celsius, draw it into a hair-thin thread, then coat it in layers of protective polymer. The process is so precise that the glass core is 8.2 microns wide -- 12 times thinner than a red blood cell.

Every AI data center being built right now needs miles of this cable. Nvidia gets the headlines. Corning does the wiring.

Ticker GLW. Same company that makes your phone screen. Gorilla Glass on one side, the internet's backbone on the other.
cta: Follow along. Next time -- a machine that cuts jet engine parts from a solid block of metal. This is Becknology, where markets meet machines.
broll: Fiber optic draw tower, glass preform close-up, data center cable runs

title: Amazon Now Has 1 Million Robots
body:
Amazon just crossed 1 million robots in its warehouses. That's not a typo. One million.

Hercules and Pegasus drive units -- 250 pounds each, carrying 1,250 more -- transport inventory pods across football-field-sized fulfillment centers. Sparrow uses computer vision to pick individual items. Proteus navigates around human workers with no fences, no rails, no pre-programmed paths.

Their newest facility in Shreveport runs Sequoia -- a system that orchestrates all of these robots together in a single building. One brain. A million hands.

Ticker AMZN. They're not a retailer anymore. They're a robotics company that happens to sell you stuff.
cta: Next time -- the sensor that catches defects smaller than a human hair. This is Becknology, where markets meet machines.
broll: Amazon fulfillment center aerial, Proteus robot moving autonomously, Sparrow robotic arm picking

title: This Sensor Checks 10,000 Parts Per Minute
body:
A SICK vision sensor mounted above a conveyor belt inspects 10,000 parts per minute. It catches defects smaller than a human hair -- 0.01mm off and the part gets rejected.

A camera, a laser, and AI. That's it. The laser hits the surface, the camera reads the reflection, and the AI decides pass or fail in under 6 milliseconds.

Every major automaker on Earth uses these. BMW, Toyota, Ford -- their quality control doesn't rely on human eyes anymore. It relies on a German company most investors have never heard of.

SICK AG. 2.3 billion euros in revenue. 12,000 employees. Sensors in every factory you've never visited.
cta: Stick around. Next time -- a $7 billion company hiding inside every vending machine. This is Becknology, where markets meet machines.
broll: SICK vision sensor on conveyor, laser inspection close-up, automotive quality line

title: A $7 Billion Company Inside Every Vending Machine
body:
Every time you put a dollar in a vending machine, a device you've never seen validates it in 0.1 seconds.

It reads the magnetic signature, measures the width to 0.01mm, checks the infrared pattern, and compares it against a database of every known counterfeit. All before the dollar hits the tray.

Crane NXT makes that device. Vending machines, ATMs, self-checkout lanes, casino slot machines -- if a machine accepts cash anywhere in the world, Crane is probably inside it.

Ticker CR. $7 billion market cap. Completely invisible. That's the point.
cta: Next time -- the connector nobody talks about that's in every single electric vehicle. This is Becknology, where markets meet machines.
broll: Vending machine bill validator close-up, ATM cash handling, self-checkout terminal

title: 3,000 Connections. Every Single EV.
body:
Every electric vehicle has 3,000+ electrical connections. Every single one needs a connector that can handle 800 volts without failing.

Not the battery. Not the motor. The tiny metal-and-plastic pieces that make electricity flow from the battery pack to the drive unit to the infotainment system. One bad connector at 800 volts and the car catches fire.

Amphenol makes more connectors than anyone on Earth. $6 billion in quarterly revenue. Sales up 50% year over year. They're in every EV, every data center, every fighter jet, every satellite.

Ticker APH. $90 billion company. Nobody talks about them. That's insane.
cta: Follow along. Next time -- a 5-axis machine that carves jet engine blades from solid metal. This is Becknology, where markets meet machines.
broll: EV wiring harness, Amphenol high-voltage connector, data center cabling

title: This Machine Carves a Jet Engine Blade From Solid Metal
body:
A 5-axis CNC machine takes a solid block of titanium and carves a jet engine turbine blade in 4 hours. No welds. No joints. One continuous piece of metal.

It moves on 5 axes simultaneously. The cutting tool spins at 20,000 RPM while the workpiece tilts, rotates, and shifts. Accuracy to 0.001mm -- that's 1/70th the width of a human hair.

A human machinist with the best tools on Earth would take a week. This machine does it before lunch.

DMG Mori makes these machines. They're German-Japanese. They make the machines that make the machines. When politicians say "advanced manufacturing" -- this is literally what they mean.
cta: This is Becknology, where markets meet machines. Follow for more.
broll: 5-axis CNC cutting titanium, turbine blade close-up, DMG Mori machine center
